University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

Toward þᵉ toun of Rome goth her wey
To Rome is come þis holy creature
And fyndeth her frendes þ̉ere boþe hole ⁊and sounde
Now is she skaped all here aduenture
And when she her fader hath yfounde
Doune on her knees falleth she to grounde
Wepynge for tendernesse in hert blythe
She heryeth god an hondred þousand sythe
In v̉ertu ⁊and in holy almes dede
Þey lyuen all ⁊and neuʳ sonder wende
Tyl deth departed hem þis lyf þey lede
And fareth now well my tale is atte an ende
Now Ihc cⁱst þat of his myht may sende
Ioy aftʳ wo gouerne vs in his gᵃce
And kepe vs alle þat ben in þis place
Oure ost vpon his styrop styrte anon
And seyde gode men herkeneth euʳychon
Þis was a þrifty tale for þᵉ nones
Syre parysch pst qd he for godes bones
Telle vs a tale as was þi foreward ȝore
I see well þᵗat ye lerned men in lore
Can muche gode by godes dignete
Þᵉ ꝑparson answerede Benedicite
What eyleth þis mon so synfully to swere
Oure ost answered O Iankyn be ȝe þere
Now gode men qd oure ost herkeneth me
I smelle a lollard in þᵉ wynde qd he
Abyde for godes digne passioıı̄unn
Þauh ȝe stynte on þis grene here a doıı̄unn
Þis lollard wyl pche vs here som what
Nay by my fadre saule þat shal he nouht
Seyde þe Sompnoᵘur he shal here not pʳche
He shall no gospell here glose ne teche
We leeuen all in þe grete god qd he
He wolde desohdesohdesome difficulte
Or springen cockel in oure clene corn
And þ̉erfore ost I warne þᵉ beforn
My Ioly body shall a tale telle
And I shall clynken ȝow so mery a belle
But hit shalnot be of Philosophie
Ne of ars megik ne Astroologie
Ne physyk ne termes queynt of lawe
Þ̉er is but lyttel latyn in my mawe
Atte Surrie in þˢis lond of tartari
Þ̉ere dwelled a kyng þᵗat worred bysyly
Þoruh wych þ̉er died many a douhti man
Þis noble king was called Cambuscan
Wych in his tyme was of so gret renoun
Þᵗat þ̉er was nowhere in no regioun̄
So excellent a lord in all þing
Hym lacked not þᵗat longed to a king

A fayre ꝑperson̄e he was and fortunate
Þat þ̉er was nowhere a ryaller͗e man
Þis noble king þis tartre þis Cambuscan
Had two sones bi Eltheta his wyf
Of þᵉ wych þᵉ eldest heyth Algersyf
Þᵗat oþᵘur was called Camballo
A douhter had þis worþ king also
Þᵗat ȝongest was ⁊and heyth Canace
But forte telle ȝow all beaute
Hit lith not in my tonge ne in my cōnnyng
I dar not vndᵘur take so hye a þing
Myn englyssh eke is Insufficient
Hit moste be a Reithor excellent
Þᵗat couthe his coloures longyng for þᵗat art
Ȝif he shulde discerne in any part
I am no such I mote speke as I can
And so befell þᵗat þis Cambuscan
Hath twenty wyntᵘur boren his diademe
As he was wond fro ȝer to ȝer to done
He let þᵉ feste of his Natiuite
Doon crien þoruh sarray his sitee
Þᵉ last ydus of marche aftre þᵉ ȝere
Phebus þᵉ sonne full Ioly was ⁊and clere
For he was nyh his exaltacioun̄
In marces face ⁊and in his mansioun̄
In Aries þᵉ coleryk þᵉ hote signe
Full lusty was þᵉ wedur ⁊and benigne
For wych þᵉ foules agayn þᵉ sonne shene
Wherfore þᵉ sesoun̄ ⁊and þᵉ ȝonge grene
Ful lowde sang her affectiouns
Hit semeth þei haue gete hem ꝓprotectiouns
Agayns þᵉ swerd of wyntᵘur kene ⁊and cold
Þis Cambuscan of wych I haue ȝow told
In real vestement sittes on his deys
Wᵗith dyane ful heye in his paleys
And haldes his fest so real ⁊and so Riche
Þat in al þis world þ̉er is noon suche
Of wych ȝif I sholde telle al þᵉ aray

And eke hit nedeth not to deuise
At euᵘury cours þᵉ ordre ⁊and þᵉ s̉eruise
I wyl not telle of her strange sewes
Ne of her swannes ne of her heren sewes
Eke in þat land as tellen knyhtes olde
Þ̉er is som mete þat is full deynte holde
Þᵗat in þis land men reche of hit but small
Þ̉er is no man þᵗat hit may rehercen all
I wyl not tarie ȝow for hit is pⁱrime
And for hit is no fruyt but losse of tyme
Vnto my fyrste pᵘurpos I wyl haue my recours
And so befell þᵗat aftᵘur þᵉ þridde cours
Whyles þat þis king sitteth in nobley
Herkinge his mynstralles hure thynges to pley
Byforn hym at þᵉ bord deliciously
In at þᵉ halle dore all sodeynly
Þ̉er cam a knyth vpon a stede of bras
And in his hond a brod Miroᵘur of glas
Vpon his þombe he had of gold a ryng
And bi his syde a naked swerd hangyng
And vp he rideth to þᵉ heye bord
In al þᵉ halle ne was þ̉ere spoke a word
For m̉erveyle of þis knyth hym to beholde
Ful bisily þei wenten ȝonge ⁊and olde
Þis strange knyth þᵗat cometh þus sodeynly
All armed saue his hed full Richely
Salued þᵉ king ⁊and quene ⁊and lordes all
By ordre as þey sitten in þᵉ hall
Wᵗith so gret reủerence ⁊and obeysaunce
Þat Gawen of his grete curtesie
Þeyh he come agayn out of pharie
Ne couthe hym nought amende wᵗith no word
And aftᵘur þis before þᵉ heye bord
He wᵗith a manly voys seyde his message
Aftᵘur þᵉ forme vsed in his langage
Wᵗith oute vice of sillable or of letture
And for his tale shulde seme þᵉ bettre
Acordaunt to his wordes was his chere

All be hit þauh I can not shewe his style
Ȝet say I þis that as to cōmmune entent
Þus muche amoūnteth all þᵗat euᵘur he ment
Ȝif hit so be þat I haue hit in mynde
He seyde þᵉ king of arabie ⁊and of Inde
My liege lord on þis solempne day
Salueth ȝow as he best can ⁊and may

By me þᵗat am al redy at ȝoure hest
Þis stede of bras þᵗat esely ⁊and well
Can in þᵉ space of a day naturell
Þis is to sey in XXiiijᵗⁱ houres
Wher so ȝe lust in drought or in shoures
Beren ȝoure body in to euᵘury place
Wych ȝoure hert wylleth to pace
Wᵗith oute wem of ȝow þoruh foule or fayre
Or ȝif ȝe lyst to flee als heyh in þᵉ eyre
As an Egle when hym lust to sore
Þis same stede shall bere ȝow euᵘur more
Wᵗith oute harm tyl ȝe be þ̉ere ȝe lyst
Þeyh þᵗat ȝe slepen on his bak ⁊and rest
And tᵘurne agayn wᵗith þᵉ writhyng of a pynne
He þᵗat hit wrouht couht full many a gynne
He awayted many a constellacioıı̄un
Er he had done þis oꝑperacioıı̄un
And knewe ful many a seal ⁊and mony a bande
Þis meroᵘur eke þat I haue in myn hande
Hath such a myht þᵗat men may in hit see
Whenne þ̉er shall falle any adủersitee
Vn to youre regne regne reygne or vn to ȝour͗e self also
And openly telle who is ȝoure frend or foo
And ouᵘur all þis ȝif any lady briht
Hath sette her hert on any oþᵘur whyth
Ȝif she be fals she shall þᵉ treson see
His newe loue ⁊and all his subtilte
So openly þᵗat þ̉er shall no þing hyde
Whefore agayns þis lusty som̉eres tide
This meroᵘur ⁊and þis ryng þᵗat ȝe may see
He hath send to my lady Canace
Ȝour͗e excellent doghtᵘur þat is here
Þᵉ v̉ertu of þis ryng ȝif ȝe wyl here
Is þis who luste hit forte were
Vpon her þombe or in her purse bere
Þ̉er is no foule þᵗat flyeth vndᵘur heuen
Þat she ne shal vnder take his steuen̄e
And knowe his menynge openly ⁊and pleyn̄ vpon hir þou be or in hir purse here
And answere hym in his langage ageyn
Þat euᵘury gras þᵗat groweth upon Rote
She shall knowe ⁊and whom it wyl don bote
All be his woundes neuᵘur so wyde
Þis naked swerd þᵗat hongeth by my syde
Such v̉ertu hath þᵗat what man so ȝe smyte
Þoruh out his armure hit wyl kerue ⁊and byte
Were hit as þyk as any ook
And what man is wounded wᵗith þat strok
Shall neuᵘur be hole to ȝow lyst of gᵃrace
To stroke hym wᵗith þᵉ platte swerd in þilke place
Þ̉ere he his hurt þis is as muche to sayne
Ȝe most wᵗith þᵉ plat swerd agayne
Stroke hym in þᵉ wounde ⁊and hit shall close
Þis is a verrey soth wᵗith oute glose
Hit fayleth not whiles hit is in ȝoure hold
And when þis knyth þus his tale told
He rideth out of þᵉ halle ⁊and doun he lyht
His stede wyche þᵗat shon as sonne bryht
Standeth in þe court stille as any ston
Þis knyht is in to his Chambre lad anon̄
He us vn arrayed ⁊and to þᵉ mete sett
Þᵉ p̉resaunttes beth full Richely sett
Þis is to say þᵉ swerd ⁊and þᵉ meroᵘur
Al born was in to þᵉ heye tour
Wᵗith certeyn officeres ordeyned þ̉erfore
And to Canace þis Ryng is bore
Solempnely þ̉ere she sat at þᵉ table
But sykerly wᵗith oute any fable
Þᵉ hors of bras þᵗat may not be remeued
Hit stond as hit were to þᵉ grounde glewed
Þ̉er may no man out of þᵉ place hit dryue
For engyne wyndas ne polyue
And þᵉ cause why for þei couht not þᵉ craft
And th̉erfore in þᵉ paleys þei haue hym laft
Tyl þᵗat þᵉ knyth haþ tauht hem þᵉ maner
To voyden hym as ȝe shull aftᵘur her
Grete was þᵉ prees swarmynge to ⁊and fro
To gauren on þis stede þᵗat stondeth so
For hit so wyde was so brode ⁊and long
So well ꝓproporciount to be strong
Ryth as hit were a stede of lombardie
Þ̉erto so horsly ⁊and so quyk of Eye
As hit a gentyl polyus courser were
For certes fro his tayle vn to his ere
Nature ne art couht hym amende
In all degre as all peple wende
But euᵘurmore her most wondᵘur was
How hit couth gon ⁊and was of bras
Hit was of fayreye as þᵉ peple semed
Dyuerse folk diủersely haue demed
As many hedes as many wittes þ̉er ben
Þei murmured as doth a swarme of been
And made skyles aftᵘur hir fantasyes

And sayde hit was lyke þᵉ pedase

Þat born was vp to þᵉ maystre tour

An oþᵘur answered certes hit may well be
Naturally by composiciouns

And seyden þᵗat in Rome was such oon̄

Þᵉ gentell lyon wᵗith þis adrian
Whanne þᵗat þis tartre kyng Cambuscan

Byfore hym goth þᵉ lowde mynstralcie

Þ̉ere as Þ̉ere sownen diuerse Instrumentz
Þat hit is lyke an heuene for te here

For in þᵉ vise sat her lady hy

Þis noble kyng is sette vpon his trone
Þis strange knyth is fet to hym ful sone

Here is þᵉ reuell ⁊and þᵉ Iolyte
Þᵗat is not able a dul man to deuise

Þᵉ Styward comaundet spices forto hye

Ilke man wot well þᵗat at a kynges fest

Þᵗat sythe grete sege of troy was

But finally þᵉ kyng asketh þᵉ knyth

Betwyx ȝow ⁊and me ⁊and þᵗat full sone

Þᵉ man̉er ⁊and þᵉ forme of þis þing

Þis Cambuscan his lordes festynge

Þᵉ moste part but hit were canace

Þᵉ knotte why þᵗat euᵘury tale is told

This child I am comaunded for to take

And to the Sergeant mekely she sayde

Vn to youre loue and whan this Markys say

To whom that she was yeuen herte and al
As to hir verray worldly suffisance
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markys writen hath in special
A lettre in which he sheweth his entente
And secrely he to Boloigne it sente
To the Erl of Pavyk which that hadde tho
Wedded his suster prayde he specially
To bryngen hom agayn his children two
In honurable estat al openly
With all his hert ful affectuously
But o thyng he hym prayde outrely
With all his herte ful affectuously
That he to no wight thgh men wolde enquere
Sholde nat tellen whos children that they were
But seye the mayden sholde ywedded be
Vn to the Markys of Saluce anon
And as this Erl was prayd so dide he
For at day set he on his wey is gon
And forth he rod / ful fast a noon
Toward Saluce and lordes many oon
Toward Saluce / this Mayde for to gyde
In riche array this mayden for to gyde
Hir yonge brother ridyng hir bisyde
Arrayed was toward hir mariage
This fresshe mayde ful of gemmes clere
Hir brother which that seuen yeer was of age
Arrayed eek ful fressh in his manere
And thus in gret noblesse and with glad cheere
Toward Saluces shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day they ryden in hir wey
Incipit pars quinta
Among al this after his wikke vsage
Incipit pars qᵃnta et Vltima
This Markys yet his wif to tempte moore
To the outreste preue of hir corage
Fully to han experience and loore
If that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Ful boystously hath seyd hir this sentence
Certes Grisilde I hadde ynogh plesance
To han yow to my wyf for your goodnesse
As for youre trouthe and for your obeysance
Noght for your lynage ne for your richesse
But now knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in gret lordshipe if I wel auyse
Ther is gret seruitute in sondry wyse
I may nat do as euery Plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
Another wyf and cryen day by day
And eek the pope rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndertake
And trewely thus muche I wol yow seye
My newe wif is comynge by the weye
Be strong of herte and voyde anon hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Tak it agayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous quod he
No man may alwey han prosperitee
With euene herte I rede yow tendure
The strook of Fortune or of auenture
And she agayn answerde in pacience
My lord quod she I woot and wiste alway
How that bitwixen youre magnificence
And my pouerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparisoun it is no nay
I ne heeld me neuere digne in no manere
To be your wyf no ; ne youre chambrere
And in this hous ther ye me lady made
The heighe god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neuere heeld me lady ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And euere shal whil that my lyf may dure
Abouen euery worldly creature
That ye so longe of youre benygnytee
Han holden me in honour and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god and yow to whom I preye
Foryelde it yow ther is namoore to seye
Vn to my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyues ende
Ther I was fostred of a child ful smal
Til I be deed my lyf ther wol I lede
A wydewe clene in body herte and al
For sith I yaf to yow my maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyf it is no drede
God shilde swich a lordes wyf to take
Another man to housbond or to make
And of youre newe wyf god of his grace
So graunte yow wele and prosperitee
For I wol gladly yelden hir my place
In which that I was blisful wont to be
For sith it liketh yow my lord quod she
That whilom weren al myn hertes reste
That I shal goon I wol goon whan yow leste
But ther as ye me profre swich dowaire
As I first broghte it is wel in my mynde
It were my wrecched clothes no thyng faire
The whiche to me were hard now for to fynde
O goode god how gentil and how kynde
Ye semed by your speche and your visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
But sooth is seyd algate I fynde it trewe
For in effect it proued is on me
Loue is noght old as whan that it is newe
But certes lord for noon aduersitee
To dyen in this cas it shal nat be
That euere in word or werk I shal repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hool entente
My lord ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me strepe out of my poure wede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broghte I noght ellis out of drede
But feith and nakednesse and maydenhede
And here agayn my clothyng I restore
And eek my weddyng ryng for euere moore
The remenant of your Iewels redy be
Inwith your chambre dar I saufly sayn
Naked out of my fadres hous quod she
I cam and naked moot I turne agayn
Al youre plesance wol I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be nat youre entente
That I smoklees out of your palays wente
Ye koude nat doon so dishoneste a thyng
That thilke wombe in which youre children leye
Sholde biforn the peple in my walkyng
Be seyn al bare wher fore I yow preye
Lat me nat lyk a worm go by the weye
Remembre yow myn owene lord so deere
I was youre wyf thogh I vnworthy weere
Wher fore in gerdou of my maydenhede
Which that I broghte and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth sauf to yeue me to my mede
But swich a smok as I was wont to were
That I ther with may wrye the wombe of here
That was youre wyf and here I take my leeue
Of yow myn owene lord lest I yow greeue
The smok quod he that thow hast on thy bak
Lat it be stille and bere it forth with thee
But wel vnnethes thilke word he spak
But wente his wey for routhe and for pitee
Biforn the folk hir seluen strepeth shee
And in hir smok with heued and feet al bare
Toward hir fader hous forth is she fare
The folk hir folwen wepynge in hir weye
And Fortune ay they cursen as they goon
But she fro wepyng kepte hir eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spak she noon
Hir fader that this tidynge herde anon
Curseth the day and tyme that nature
Shoop hym to been a lyues creature
For out of doute this olde poure man
Was euere in suspect of hir mariage
For euere he demed sith that it bigan
That whan the lord fulfild hadde his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disperage
To wedde oon of so pore alynage
To his estat so lowe for talighte
And voyden hir as soone as euere he myghte
Agayns his doghter hastiliche goth he
For he by noyse of folk knew hir comynge
And with hir olde cote as it myghte be
He couered hire ful sorwefully wepynge
But on hir body myghte he it nat brynge
For rude was the clooth and she moore of age
By dayes fele than at hir mariage
Thus with hir fader for a certein space
Dwelleth this flour of wifly pacience
That neyther by hir wordes ne hir face
Biforn the folk ne eek in hir absence
Ne shewed she that hir was doon offence
Ne of hir heighe estat no remembrance
Ne hadde she as by hir contenance
No wonder is for in hir grete estat
Hir goost was euere in pleyn humylitee
No tendre mouth noon herte delicat
No pompe no semblant of realtee
But ful of pacient benygnytee
Discreet and pridelees ay honurable
And to hir housbonde euere meke and stable
Men speke of Iob and moost for his hunblenesse
As clerkes whan hem lest konne wel endite
Namely of men but as in soothfastnesse
Thogh clerkes preyse wommen but alite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wommen kan ne kan be half so trewe
As wommen been but it be falle of newe

Incipit pars Sexta
Fro Boloigne is this Erl of Pavyk come
Of which the fame vp sprong to moore and lesse
And to the peples erys alle and some
Was kouth eek that a newe Markisesse
He with hym broghte in swich pomp and richesse
That neuere was ther seyn with mannes eye
So noble array in al westlumbardye
The Markys which that shoop and knew al this
Er that this Erl was come sente his message
For thilke sely poure Grisildis
And she with humble herte and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thoght in hir corage
Cam at his heste and on hir knees hir sette
And reuerently and wysly she hym grette
Grisilde quod he my wyl is outrely
This mayden that shal wedded been to me
Receyued be tomorwe as really
As it possible is in myn hous to be
And eek that euery wight in his degree
Haue his estat in sittyng and seruyse
And heigh plesance as I kan best deuyse
I haue no wommen suffisant certayn
The chambres for taraye in ordynance
After my lust and ther fore wolde I fayn
That thyn were al swich manere gouernance
Thow knowest eek of old al my plesance
Though thyn array be badde and yuel biseye
Do thow thy deuoir at the leeste weye
Nat oonly lord that I am glad quod she
To doon youre lust but I desire also
Yow for to serue and plese in my degree
With outen feyntyng and shal euere mo
Ne neuere for no wele ne no wo
Ne shal the goost with Inne myn herte stente
To loue yow best with al my trewe entente
And with that word she gan the hous to dighte
And tables for to sette and beddes make
And peyned hir to doon al that she myghte
Preyynge the chambreres for goddes sake
To hasten hem and faste swepe and shake
And she the mooste seruysable of alle
Hath euery chambre arrayed and his halle
Abouten vndren gan this Erl alighte
That with hym broghte thise noble children tweye
For which the peple ran to seen the sighte
Of hire array so richely biseye
And thanne at erst amonges hem they seye
That Walter was no fool thogh that hym leste
To chaunge his wyf for it was for his beste
For she is fairer as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde and moore tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And moore plesant for hir heigh lynage
Hir brother eek so fair was of visage
That hem to seen the peple hath caught plesance
Commendynge now the Markys gouernance
O stormy peple vnsad and euere vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungynge as a vane
Delitynge euere in rumbel that is newe
Here may ye se the peple how newe
For lyk the moone ay wexe ye and wane
Ay ful of clappyng deere ynow a Iane
And changeable be right as the mane
Youre doom is fals youre constance yuele preueth
A ful greet fool is he that on yow leueth
Thus seyden sadde folk in that Citee
Whan that the peple gazed vp and doun
For they were glad right for the noueltee
To han a newe lady of hir town
Namoore of this make I now mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wol I me dresse
And telle hir constance and hir bisynesse
Ful bisy was Grisilde in euery thyng
That to the feste was apertinent
Right noght was she abayst of hir clothyng
Thogh it were rude and somdel eek to rent
But with glad cheere to the yate is she went
With oother folk to greete the Markysesse
And after that dooth forth hir bisynesse
With so glad cheere his gestes she receyueth
And so konnyngly euerich in his degree
That no defaute no man aparceyueth
But ay they wondren what she myghte be
That in so poure array was for to se
And koude swich honour and reuerence
And worthily they preysen hir prudence
In al this mene while she ne stente
This mayde and eek hir brother to commende
With al hir herte in ful benygne entente
So wel that no man koude hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that thise lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was bisy in his halle
Grisilde quod he as it were in his pley
How liketh thee my wyf and hir beautee
Right wel quod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saw I neuere noon than she
I prey to god yeue hire prosperritee
And so hope I that he wol to yow sende
Plesance ynogh vn to youre lyues ende
O thyng biseke I yow and warne also
That ye ne prike with no tormentynge
This tendre mayden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hir norissynge
Moore tendrely and to my supposynge
She koude nat aduersitee endure
As koude a poure fostred creature
And whan this Walter saw hir pacience
Hir glad cheere and no malice at al
And he so ofte had doon to hir offence
And she ay sad and constant as a wal
Continuynge euere hir Innocence ouer al vbique
With pacience Grisild he quiteth
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vp on hir wifly stedfastnesse
This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now namoore agast ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith and thy benygnytee
Mankynde which that he wroght
As wel as euere womman was assayed
In greet estat and poureliche arrayed
Now knowe I deere wyf thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took and gan hir kesse
And she for wonder took of it no keep
She herde nat what thyng he to hir seyde
She ferde as she hadde stirt out of a sleep
Sche ferd as sche had stert oute of hir slepe
Til she out of hir mazednesse abreyde
Grisilde quod he by god that for vs deyde
Thow art my wyf noon oother I haue
Ne neuere hadde as god my soule saue
This is thy doghter which thow hast supposed
To be my wyf that oother feithfully
Shal be myn heir as I haue ay supposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kept hem priuely
Tak hem agayn for now maistow nat seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thy children tweye
And folk that oother weys han seyd of me
I warne hem wel that I haue doon this dede
For no malice ne for no crueltee
But for tassaye in thee thy wommanhede
And nat to sleen my children god forbede
But for to kepe hem pryuely and stille
Til I thy purpos knewe and al thy wille
Whan she this herde aswowne doun she falleth
For pitous ioye and after hir swownynge
She bothe hir yonge children vn to hir calleth
And in hir armes pitously wepynge
Embraceth hem and tendrely kissynge
Ful lyk a moder with hir salte terys
She batheth bothe hir visage and hir herys
O which a pitous thyng it was to se
O such a pitous thing it was to see
Hir swownyng and hir humble voys to heere
Grant mercy lord god thanke it yow quod she
That ye han saued me my children deere
Now rekke I neuere to been ded right heere
Sith I stonde in your loue and in youre grace
No fors of deeth ne whan my spirit pace
O tendre o deere o yonge children myne
Youre woful moder wende stedefastly
That cruel houndes or som foul vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his mercy
And youre benygne fader tendrely
Hath doon yow kept and in that same stounde
Al sodeynly she swapte adoun to grounde
And in hir swogh so sadly holdeth she
Hir children two whan she gan hem tembrace
That with greet sleghte and greet difficultee
The children from hir arm they gonne arace
O many a teer o many a pitous face
Doun ran of hem that stoden hir bisyde
Vnnethe aboute hir myghte they abyde
Walter hir gladeth and hir sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hir traunce
And euery wight hir ioye and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hir contenaunce
Walter hir dooth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deyntee for to seen the cheere
Bitwix hem two now they ben met yfeere
Thise ladies whan that they hir tyme say
Han taken hir and in to chambre goon
And strepen hir out of hir rude aray
And in a clooth of gold that brighte shoon
With a coroune of many a riche stoon
Vp on hir hed they in to halle hir broghte
And ther she was honured as hir oghte
Thus hath this pitous day a blisful ende
For euery man and womman dooth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne shoon the sterres lyght
For moore solempne in euery mannes syght
This feste was and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
Ful many a yeer in heigh prosperitee
Lyuen thise two in concord and in reste
And richely his doghter maried he
Vn to a lord oon of the worthyeste
Of al Ytaille and thanne in pees and reste
His wyues fader and his court he kepeth
Til that the soule out of his body crepeth
His sone succedeth in his heritage
In reste and pees after his fader day
And fortunat was eek his mariage
Al putte he nat his wyf in gret assay
This world is nat so strong it is no nay
As it hath been in olde tymes yore
And herkneth what this Auctour seith therfore
This storie is seyd nat for that wyues sholde
Folwen Grisilde as in humylitee
For it were inpor table thogh they wolde
But for that euery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in aduersitee
As was Grisilde therfore Petrak writeth
This storie which he with heigh stile enditeth
For sith a womman was so pacient
Vn to a mortal man wel moore vs oghte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For gret skile is he preue that he wroghte
But he ne tempteth no man that he boghte
As seith Seint Iame if ye his pistel rede
He preueth folk al day it is no drede
And suffreth vs as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of aduersitee
Ful ofte to be bete in sondry wise
Nat for to knowe oure wyl for certes he
Er we were born knew al oure freletee
And for oure beste is al his gouernance
Lat vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffrance
But o word lordynges herkneth er I go
It were ful hard to fynde now a dayes
In al a town Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put to swiche assayes
The gold of hem hath now so badde alayes
With bras that thogh the coigne be fair at eye
It wolde rather breste atwo than plye
For which heere for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyf and al hir secte god mayntene
In heigh maistrie or ellis were it scathe
I wol with lusty herte fressh and grene
Seye yow a song to glade yow I wene
And lat vs stynte of ernestful matere
Herkneth my song that seith in this manere

And þenne he sang hit well ⁊and baldely
Fro word to word acordynge wᵗith þᵉ note
Twey a day hit passeth þoruh his þrote
To scole ward ⁊and homward when he went
On cⁱstes modʳ sette was his entent
¶ As I haue sayd þourhout þᵉ iewerie
Þis littell chyld as he cam to ⁊and fro
Full merely þan wold he synge ⁊and crye
O alma redemptoris euʳ mo
Þᵉ swetnesse hath here herte ꝑperced so
Of cⁱstes modʳ þᵗat to her to pᵃy
He can not stynte of syngynge by þᵉ way
¶ Oure fyrste foo þᵉ spent sathanas
Þᵗat hath in iewes hes his waspes nest
Vp swall ⁊and seyde O Ebrekꝭes peple allas
His þis a þing to ȝow þᵗat is honest
Þat such a boy shall walk as hym lest
In ȝoure dispyt ⁊and synge of such sentence
Whyche is agayns ȝoure lawes reủerence
¶ Fro þennes forth þᵉ iewes haue conspyred
Þis Innocent out of þis world to chace
In homicide þ̉erto haue þey hyred
Þᵗat in an Aley hadde a pⁱriue place
And as þis chyld gan for by for to pace
Þis cursed Iew hym hent ⁊and held hym faste
And kutte his þrote ⁊and in a pⁱriue hym caste
¶ I sey þᵗat in a wardrop he hym þrewh
Where as þis iewes purgen entrayll
O cursed folk of þᵉ heroudes all newe
What may ȝoure euell entent ȝow avayle
Murdre wyl out certeyn hit wyll not fayle
And nameli þ̉ere þᵉ honoᵘur of god sholde sprede
Þᵉ blood out cryeth in ȝoure cursede dede
¶ O martyr sowded to vⁱginitee
Now mayst þᵘ synge folewynge euʳ in oon
Þᵉ whyte lamb celestiall qd she
Of whyche þᵉ grete Euᵃngelyst seint Iohn
In pathmos wrot whiche sayen þei þᵗat goon
Byfore þis lamb ⁊and syngen a song all newe
Þᵗat neuʳ Flesshly wymmen þey knewe
¶ Þis pore wydewe awayteth al nyth
Aftʳ þis lyttell chyld but hit cam nouht
For whyche as sone as hit was dayes lyth
Wᵗith face pale ⁊and drede ⁊and bysy þouht
She hath at scole ⁊and elles where hym souht
Tyll fynally she can so ferre Aspye
Þᵗat he was seyen last in þᵉ iewerye
¶ Wᵗith modres pytte in her brest enclosed
She goth as she were half out of her mynde
To euʳy place where she hath supposed
By lykkly hede her chyld to fynde
And euʳ on cⁱstes modʳ meke ⁊and kynde
She cryed ⁊and at þᵉ last þus she wrouth
Among þᵉ cursed iewes she hym south
¶ She frayneth ⁊and pᵃyeth pittously
To euʳy iew þᵗat dwelleth in þᵗat place
To telle her ȝif ouht her chyld went for by
Þey sayde nay but ihc of his gᵃce
Ȝaf in her þouht in whych a lyttell space
Þat in þᵗat place aftʳ her sone she cⁱed
Wher þᵗat he was cast in put bysyde
¶ O grete god þᵗat ꝑperfourmest þi lond
By mouht of Innocence lo here þi myth
Þis gēmme of chastite þis Emeraude
And eke of martyrdome þᵉ rubye bryht
Þ̉ere he wᵗith þrote ycorue ley vpryht
O Alma redemptoris con to syng
So loude þᵗat all þᵉ place gan to ryng
¶ The cⁱsten folkꝭes þat þoruh þᵉ strete went
In comen forto wondren on þis þing
And hastely þei for tho ꝓprouost sent
He cam anon wᵗith oute tarying
And heryeth cⁱst þᵗat is of heuene kyng
And eke his modʳ honoᵘur of mankynde
And aftʳ þat þᵉ iewes let hym bynde
¶ Þis chyld wᵗith pytous lamentacioun
Vp taken was syngynge his song Alwey
And wᵗith honoᵘur of grete ꝓprocessioun
Þey caryen hym vn to þᵉ next abbey
Hys modʳ swonynge by þᵉ bere lay
Vn nethes myth þᵉ peple þᵗat was þere
Þis newe rachell bringe fro þᵉ bere
¶ Wᵗith turment ⁊and wᵗith shamefull deth ilke on
Þis ꝓprouost doth þis iewes forto st̉erue
Þᵗat of þis murdre wyst ⁊and þat Anon
He nolde such cursednesse obserue
Euel shall haue þᵗat euell woll deserue
Þ̉erfore wᵗith wylde hors he dyd hem drawe
And aftʳ þat he hyng hem by þᵉ lawe
¶ Vpon þᵉ bere ay lyth þis Innocent
Byforn þᵉ chief autre whyles þᵗat masse last
And aftʳ þat þᵉ abbot wᵗith his couent
Sped hem for to buryen hym full fast
And when þᵉ haly watʳ on hym cast
Ȝut spak þis chyld when spreynt was holywatʳ
And sang o alma redemptoris mat̉er
¶ Þis abbot whyche þat was an holy man
As monkes ben or elles sholde be
Þis ȝonge chyld to cōniure he began
And seyde dere chyld I halse þe
In þᵉ v̉ertue of þᵉ holy tⁱnite
Tell me what is þi cause for to syng
Sythns þᵗat þy throte is kut at my semyng
¶ My þrote is kut vn to my necke bon
Seyde þis chylde as by wey of kynde
I sholde haue dyed longe tyme Agone
But ihc cⁱst as ȝe in bokes fynde
Woll þᵗat his glorie last ⁊and be in mynde
And for þᵉ worshype of his modʳ dere
Ȝit may y synge O alma lowde ⁊and clere
¶ Þis welle of mercy cⁱstes moder swete
I loued alwey ⁊and aftʳ my cōnnyng
And when þᵗat y my lyf sholde lete
To me she cam ⁊and bad me for to syng
This antym verrely in my dying
As ȝe haue herd ⁊and when þᵗat y had song
Me þouht she leyde a greyne vpon my tong
¶ Wherfore y synge ⁊and synge mot certeyne
In honoᵘur of þat blesfull mayde free
Tyl fro my tonge is þᵗat greyne
And aftʳ þat þus seyde she to me
My littel chyld now wyl I fecche þe
When þᵗat þᵉ greyne is fro my tonge ytake
Be nouth agast y wyl þe nouht for sake
¶ Þis holy monk þis Abbot mene I
His tonge out cauht ⁊and toke a wey þᵉ greyne
And he ȝaf vp þᵉ gost full softely
And when þis Abbot had þis wondʳ seyn
His salte teres stryked doun as reyne
And gruf he fell al platte doune to grounde
And stylle he ley as he hadde ben ybounde
¶ Þᵉ Couent eke ley vpon þᵉ pauyment
Wepynge ⁊and heryinge cⁱstes modre dere
And aftʳ þᵗat þey rysen ⁊and forth þey went
And toke awey þis martyr fro þᵉ bere
And in a tombe of marble stones clere
Enclosen þey þis lytell body swete
Þ̉ere he is now god leue vs forte mete
¶ O ȝong hewe o lincoln sleyne also
Wᵗith cursede iewes as hit is notable
For hit is but a lyttell whyle ago
Preye eke for vs we synfull folk vnstable
For of his mercy god so mercyable
On vs his grete mercy multipley
For reủerence of his modʳ marie
When sayde was þis mueyle euʳy man
As sobre was þat wondre was to see
Tyl þᵗat oure oure ost Iape to beganne
And þanne at þᵉ erst he loked vpon me . s . Chauser
And seyde þus what man art þᵘ qd he
Thow lokest as þᵘ wolde fynde an hare
For euʳ vpon þᵉ ground y see þe stare
¶ Aproche nere ⁊and loke meryly
Now ware ȝow syres ⁊and lete þis man haue place
He in þᵉ wast is shapen as well as y
Þis were a popet in armes to enbrace
For any wōmman smal ⁊and fayre of face
He semeth Eluyssh by his contynaunce
For vn to no wyht doth he daliaunce
¶ Sey now somwhat sythns oþʳ folk haue seyd
Telle vs a tale of myrthe ⁊and þat anon
Ost qd I ne beth not euel apayd
For oþʳ tale certes con y noon
But of a ryme y lerned ȝore agon
Ȝe þᵗat is good qd he nowe shulle we here
Som deynteth þing me þinketh by his chier
Lvsteneth lordynges īn gode entent
And I wyll telle v̉erament
Of myrþe ⁊and of sola
Al of a knyht was fayre ⁊and gent
In batayle ⁊and in turnament
His name was ʆsir th
Iborn he was in fer contre
In flaundres all be ȝonde þᵉ see
At poperyng in þᵉ place
His fadʳ was a man ful free
A lord he was of þat contree
As hit was godes gᵃce
Syre Thophas was a douhty swayn
Whyte was his face as payndemayn
His lyppes red as a rose
His rode lyke skarlet in greyne
And I ȝow telle in gode certeyne

Þᵉ heer of his berd was lyke saferen

Þᵗat cost many a peny

Þ̉erto he was a gode archier
Of wrastelyng was þ̉er non his peer
Þ̉ere any man sholde stand
Ful many a mayde briht in boure
Þey morne for hym as ꝐParamour
When þei were bette to slepe
But he was chast ⁊and no lechoᵘur
And sote as is þᵉ brembre floᵘur
Þat bereth þᵉ rede heep
And so befell vpon a day
For soþe as I ȝow telle may
ʆsir thopas wolde out ride
He worth vpon his stede grey
And in his hond a launce gay
A long swerd by hys syde
He pⁱricked þoruh a fayre forest
Þ̉ere is many a wylde best
Ȝe boþe bucke ⁊and hare
And as he pⁱricketh north ⁊and est
I telle ȝow hym had almest
Bytyd a sore care
Þ̉ere is no swettʳ galyngale
Þᵉ lykorys ⁊and þᵉ sedewale
Ne þᵉ sote gylofre
And notemyg to put in Ale
Wheþʳ hit be moyst or stale
Or for to ley in cofre
Þᵉ briddes syngen hit is no nay
Þᵉ sꝑparhauk ⁊and þᵉ popyn iay
Þᵗat ioye hit was to here
Þᵉ þrestelcok made eke his lay
Þᵉ wode doffe vpon þᵉ spray
He song full loude ⁊and clere
Syr̉e thophas fell in loue longyng
All when he herde þᵉ þrestell synge
⁊and pⁱriked as he were wode
His fayre stede in his pⁱrikyng
So swatte þᵗat men myht hym wryng
His sydes were al blode
Syre thophas eke so wery was
For pⁱrikynge on þᵉ softe gras
So fers was his corage
Þan doun he leyde hym in þᵉ place
To make his stede som solace
⁊and ȝaf hym good forage
O seynte marie bndicite
What eyleth þis loue at me
To bynde me so sore
Me dremed al þis nyht ꝑparde
An Elf queen shall my leman be
⁊and slep vndʳ my gore
And Elf queen wyl I loue ywys
For in þis world no wōmman is
Worþi to be my make
in toune
Alle oþʳ wymen y forsake
And to an Elf quene I me take
By dale ⁊and eke by doune
In to his sadell he clamb anon
And pⁱriked ouʳ style ⁊and ston
An Elf queen to aspye
Tyl he so long hath riden ⁊and gone
Þᵗat he fond in a pⁱriue wone
Þᵉ contr̉e of fayrie
So wylde
For in þᵗat contre was þ̉er noon
neyþʳ wyf ne chylde
Tyl þ̉er cam a grete gyaunt
His name was cleped syre Olyphant
A ꝑperelous man of dede
He seyde chyld by tormegant
But ȝif þᵗat þᵘ pⁱrike out of my haunt
Anon y sle þi stede
Wᵗith mace
Here is þᵉ queen of fayrie
Wᵗith harp pipe ⁊and symphonye
Dwellynge in þis place
Þᵉ chyld seyde as I thee
To morn wyl I mete þe
When I haue myn armyre
And ȝitt I hope ꝑpar ma fey
Þᵗat þᵘ shalt wᵗith þis launcegay
Abyen hit full soure
Shall y perce ȝif y may
Or hit be fully pⁱrime of day
For here þᵘ shalt be slawe
Syr thophas drowh abak fullfast
Þis geaunt at hym stones cast
Out of a fel staf slynge
But fayre askaped Child thophas
And al hit was þoruh godes gᵃce
⁊and þoruh his fayre berynge
Ȝe lusteneth lordynges to my tale
Merioᵘur þan þᵉ nyhtyngale
For now I wyl ȝow ronne
How ʆsir thophas wᵗith sydes smale
Pⁱkynge ouʳ hull ⁊and dale
Is comen agayn to towne
His mery men comaunde he
To make boþe game ⁊and glee
For nedes moste he fyht
Wᵗith a Gyaunt wᵗith hedes þre
For a ꝐParamoᵘur ⁊and Iolyte

Do come he seyde my mynstrals

Anon þᵗat myn armynge
Of romaıı̄unces þᵗat ben realls

⁊and eke of loue lykynge
Þey fette hym fyrst þᵉ swete wyne
And mede eke in masshelyne
Or reall spicerie
Of gyngebred þᵗat was full fyn
And lykoris ⁊and eke comyn
Wᵗith sugre þᵗat is trie
He did nex his white lere
Of cloth of lake fyn ⁊and clere
A breche ⁊and eke a shert
And next his shert an Akton
And ouʳ þt an habrigeou
for ꝑpercyng of his hert
And ouʳ þat a fyne hauberk

ful strong hit was of plate
And ouʳ þᵗat his cote armure
As white as is þᵉ lylie floure
In whiche he wyl debate
Þᵉ sheld was of gold so rede
And þ̉erin was a beres hede
A charbuncle bisyde
And þ̉ere he swore on ale ⁊and bred
Þᵗat þᵉ Gyaunt shulde be ded
betyde what betyde
His Iambes were of quirboilly
His swerdes sheþe if yuory
His helm of latou bryht
His sadul was of rwell bon
His bridell as þᵉ sonne shon
Or as þᵉ mone lyht
His spere was of fyne cypes
Þᵗat bedeth werre ⁊and noþing pes
þᵉ hed full sharpe ygroıı̄unde
His stede was al dappell grey
Hit goth an amble by þᵉ wey
Full softely ⁊and rounde
Lo lordynges myn here is a fytte
Ȝif ȝe wyll more haue of hit
To telle hit wyl y fonde
No more of þis for godes dignete
Qd oure ost for þᵘ makest me
So wery of þy lewdenesse
Þa wysly god me wysse
Myres ake of þi dasty speche
Now such a ryme þᵉ deuell y beteche
Þis may well be ryme dogerell qd he
Why so qd y wyll þᵘ lette me
More of myn tale þan an oþʳ man
Sythns hit is þᵉ best ryme þᵗat y can
By god qd he pleynly y þe say
Þᵘ shalt no lengʳ ryme here to day
Þᵘ dost no þing but despendest tyme
Syre at oo word þᵘ shalt no lengʳ ryme
Let se wheþʳ þᵘ canst telle ouht in gest
Or elles in ꝓprose sıı̄unwhat þᵗat þe lest
In whyche þ̉er be som myrthe ⁊and doctⁱne
Gladly qd he by gode swete pyne
I wyll ȝow telle a littell þing in ꝓprose
Þat ouhte to lyke ȝow as y suppose
Or elles certes ȝe ben to dangerous
Hit is a morall tale v̉ertuose
Al be hit told some tyme in sondry wyse
Of sondry folk as I shall ȝow deuyse
As þus ȝe wote euʳy Euᵃngelyst
Þᵗat telleth vs þᵉ peyne of ihu cⁱst
Ne sayth al þing as his felawe doth
But naþeles her sentence is al soth
And alle acorden in here sentence

For some of hem seyn more ⁊and some sein lesse
When þᵗat þey his pytous passioun expresse
I mene of Markꝭes Mathewe luc. ⁊and Iohn

Þ̉erfore lordynges I ȝow alle beseche
Ȝif þᵗat ȝe þinke I varye in my speche
As þus ȝif þᵗat I telle somwhat more
Of ꝓprouerbes þan ȝe haue herd byfore

To enforce wᵗith þᵉ effect of my matier
And þauh I not þᵉ same wordes sey
As ȝe haue herd ȝit to alle ȝow y pᵃy
Blameth me not as for my sentence

Fro þᵉ tretys of þis sentence lyte
Aftʳ þᵉ whyche þis mery tale y wryte
Þ̉erfore herkeneth what I shall sey

div.l: Whenne ended was þᵉ tale of Mellibe
And of prudence and here benignete
Oure ost seyde as y am feythfull man
And by þᵉ pciouse corpus madrian
I hadde leuʳ þanne a barell ale
Þat good leef my wyf had herd þis tale
For she is no þing of suche pacience
As was þis Mellibes wyf dame pᵘdence
By godes bones whanne I bete my knaues
She bringeth me grete clubbed E staues
And crieth sleth þᵉ dogges euʳychon
And breketh of hem boþe bak ⁊and bon
And ȝif þᵗat any neyhboᵘur of myn
Wyll not in churche to my wyf enclyne
Or be so hardy to hure to trespas
When she cometh home she raumpeth in my face
And cⁱeth fals coward a wreke þi wyf
By godes armes I wyl haue þi knyf
And þᵘ shalt haue my distaf ⁊and go spynne
Fro day to nyth ryht þus she wyll bygynne
Allas she sayth þat euʳ I was y shape
To wedde a mylke sop or a coward ape
Þat wylle be uỏe lad wᵗith euʳy wyght
Þᵘ darste not stande by þi wyfes right
þis is my lyf but ȝif I wyll fyht
And out at þᵉ dore anou y wyll me dyht
Or elles y am lost but ȝif þat y
Be lyke a wood lyoun fooll hardy
Y wot well she wyll do me slee som day
Some nehbore and þasnne go y my way
For y am ꝑperelous wᵗith knyf in hand
Al be hit y dar not here wᵗith stand
For she is byg in armes by my fayth
Þᵗat shall he fynde þᵗat her mys doth or seyth
But lat vs passe awey fro þis matyer
My lord þᵉ monk he seyth be mery of chier
For ȝe sgull telle a tale trewely
Lowe Rouchestʳ standeth here faste by
Ryde forth myn owne lord breke not oure game
But by my trewþe y knowe not ȝoure name
Wheþʳ y shall calle ȝow my lord dame Iohn
Or dane Thomas or dane Alboıı̄un
Of what hous be ȝe gy ȝoure fadʳ kynne
Y avowe to god þᵘ hast a fayre skynne
Hit is a gentell pasture þ̉ere þᵘ in gost
Þᵘ art not lyke a penaunt or a gost
Vpon my feyth þart some officere
Some worthy sexteyn or some wothry cellerer
For by my fadʳ saule as to my dom
þU art a maystʳ when þᵘ art at hom
No pore cloysterer ne pore novys
But a gouʳnoure wyly and wys
And þ̉erwᵗith all of brawen ⁊and of bones
A well farynge psone for þᵉ nones
I pᵃy to god gyf hym confusiou
That fyrst þe brouhte in to religioun
Þᵘ wost haue be a trede fole aryȝh
Haddest þᵘ as grete leue as þᵘ hast myht
To ꝑperforme all þi lust in engendrure
Þᵘ haddest begeten many a creature
Allas why werestþso wyde a cope
God ȝeue me sorewe and y were a pope
Nouht only þᵘ but euʳy myhty man
þeygh he were shore heye vpon his pan
Shulde haue a wyf for all þis world is lorn
Religioun hath vp take all þᵉ corn
Of tredynge ⁊and we byrell men ben shrympes
Of feble trees þ̉er comen wrecched ympes
Þis maketh þᵗat oure eyres ben so sklendre
And feble þat þei may not well engendre
Þis maketh þᵗat oure wyfes wyll assaye
Religious folk for þey may bettʳ paye
Of venus payment þan may ew
God wot no lussheborne paye ȝe
But be not writh they y pley
Full often in gamen a soth y haue herd sey
Þis worthy monk toke all in pacience
And seyde y wyl don all in pacience
As ferre as sowneth in to honeste
To telle ȝow a tale or to or þre
And ȝif ȝow lyste herkeneth hyderward
I wyll ȝow telle þᵉ lyf of seynt edward
Or elles tregedise fyrst y wyl ȝow telle
Of whiche an hundreth y haue in my selle
Tregedise is for to telle a c̉erteyne storie

Ryth þus þᵉ apostel tolde vn to me

Al þis sentence me liketh euʳy del
Up stert þᵉ ꝑpardoner ⁊and þat anon
Now dame qd he by god ⁊and by seint Iohn
Ȝe beth a noble pchoᵘur in þis cas
I was aboute to wedde a wyf allas
What sholde I by hit on my flesh so dere
Ȝut had I leuʳ wedde no wyf to ȝere
Abyde qd she my tale is not begonn
Nay þᵘ shalt drinke of an oþʳ tonne
Or þᵗat y go shal sauere wers þan ale
And whanne þᵗat I haue told forth my tale
Of tⁱbulacioun in mariage
Of whiche I am expert in al myn age
This is to sey my self hath be þᵉ whyp
Þanne may þᵘ chese / ȝif þᵗat þᵘ wylt skyppe
Thilke tonne þat I shal abroche
Be ware of hit er þᵘ to nygh approche
For I shal telle ensaumples mo þan ten
Who so wyl not be ware by oþʳ men
By hym shul oþʳ men corrected be
This same wordes wryteth Ptholome
Rede in his Almagest ⁊and take hit þ̉ere

Telleth forth ȝoure tale ⁊and speleth for no man
Seyde þis ꝑpardoner as þᵗat ȝe began

Gladly qd she sithus hit may ȝow lyke
But þᵗat I pᵃy to al þis company
Ȝif þᵗat I speke aftʳ my fantasy
As taketh not agreff of þat I sey
For myn entent is not but for to play
Now ʆsir þan shal I telle my tale
As euʳ mote I drinke wyn or ale
Þᵉ thre were gode men riche ⁊and olde
Vn nethus myht þei þᵉ statute holde
In whiche þei were bounden vn to me
Ȝe wot wel what I mene of þis . ꝑpardee
As god me help I lawh whenne I think
How pytously a nyht I made hem swynk
But by my fey I tolde hit no store
Þei had gyf me her land ⁊and here tresore
Me nedeth no lengʳ do diligence
To wynnen hure loue ⁊and don hem reủerence
Þei loued me so wel by god aboue
Þat I tolde no deynteyth of hure loue
A wyse womman wyl bysye her euʳ in oon
To gete her loue þ̉ere as she hath noon
But sithus þᵗat I hem had holly in myn hond

What sholde I take kepe hem to plese
But hit were for my ꝓprofit ⁊and myn ese

Þat many a nyth þei songe weylawey

Þᵗat some men haue in Essex at Dounnawe
I goủerned hem so wel aftʳ my lawe
Þat Iche of hem ful blesful was ⁊and fawe

Thus alwey I huld hem vndʳ eye

Now herkeneth how I bar me ꝓproprely
Ȝe wyse wyfes þat can vndurstande
Thus sholde ȝe speke ⁊and bere hem wrang an hande
For half so boldely þ̉er can no man
Swere ⁊and lye as can a womman
I sey not þus by wyfes þat ben wyse
But þᵗat hit is when þei hem mys a vise
A wys wyf shal ȝif she can here goo
Bere hym an hand þat þᵉ cowe is wode

Of hure assent but herkeneth how y sayde
Syre olde caynard is þis þin array

She is honoured ouʳal where she goth
I sitte at home ⁊and haue no thryfty cloth
What dost þᵘ at myn neyhebores hous
Is she so fayre art þᵘ so amerous
What roune ȝe wᵗith oure maydenes bndicite
Syre olde lechoᵘur let þi Iapes be
And ȝif I haue a gossyp or a frend
Wᵗith oute gult ȝe chyden me as a fend
And ȝif I walke ⁊and pleye vn to hure hous
Then comest þᵘ home as drounke as a mous
And pchest on þi benche wᵗith euel preff
Þᵘ seyst to me hit is a gret mys chyeff
To wedde a pore womman for costage
And ȝif þᵗat she be riche ⁊and of gret parage
Þanne sayst þᵘ hit is a tormentrie

And ȝif þᵗat she be fayre þᵘ verrey knaue
Þᵘ sayst þᵗat euʳy holoᵘur wolde here hau
Some for her shap some for here fayrenesse
And some for she can synge ⁊and daunce
Some for here hondes ⁊and for here armes smale
Thus goth al to þᵉ deuel by þᵉ tale
Þᵘ sayst men may not kepe a castel wal

And ȝif þᵗat she be foule þᵘ sayst þat she

For as a spaynel she wolde on hym lepe
Tyl þᵗat she fynde some mon þᵗat wolde here chepe
Ne non so grey goos goth in þᵉ lake
As seyst þᵘ wyl be wᵗith oute make
And seyst hit is a wycked þing to welde
A wyght þᵗat no man his þankes wyl helde
Thus seyst þᵘ lorel whenne þᵘ gost to bedde
And þᵗat no wyse man nedeth for to wedde
Ne no man þᵗat enditeth vn to heuen
Wᵗith wylde thundre dynt ⁊and fyre leuen
Mot þi wycked necke be to broke
Þᵘ sayst þᵗat droppynge houses ⁊and eke smoke

Out of here houses a benedicite
What eyleth suche aman for to chyde
Þᵘ seyst we wyfes wyl oure vices hyde
Tyl we ben fast ⁊and þen we wyl hem shewe
Wel may þis be a ꝓprouerb of a shrewe
Þᵘ sayst þᵗat asses oxen and houndes
Þei ben assayed at diuerse stoundes
Basyns lauours er þat men hem bye
Spones stoles ⁊and such housebandrie
And so ben pottes clothes and array
But men of wymmen maken non assaye
Tyl þei ben wedded olde dotard shrewe
Þanne sayst þᵘ we wyl oure vices shewe
And seyst also hit displeseth me
But ȝif þᵘ wylt preyse my beaute
And but ȝif þᵘ poure alwey in my face
And clepe me fayre dame in euʳy place
And but þᵘ make a fest on þilke day
Þᵗat I was born ⁊and make me fressh ⁊and gay
And but þᵘ do to my Noris honoᵘur
And to my chambrer wᵗith inne my bour
And to my fadres folk ⁊and his allyes
Þus seyst þᵘ olde barel ful of lyes
And ȝut of ȝoure apprentis Iankyn
For his crysp here shynynge as gold fyn
And for he squiers me so vp ⁊and doun
Ȝut hast þᵘ cauht a fals suspecioun
I wyl hym not þeyh þᵘ were ded to morewe
But telle me þis why hydest þᵘ wᵗith sorowe
Þi keyes of þi Chist awey fro me
Hit is my good as wel as þin ꝑpardee
What wenest þᵘ to make an ydeote of oure dame
Now by þᵗat lord þat called is seint Iame
Þᵘ shalt not boþe þeyh þᵗat þᵘ were wode
Be maystre of my body ⁊and of my good
Þat oon þᵘ shalt forgon maugre þin eyen
What helpeth on me to enqueren ⁊and aspien
I trowe þᵘ woldest lok me in þin Chist
Þᵘ sholdest sey wyf go where ȝow lust
Take ȝoure desport I wyl leue no tales
I knowe ȝow for a gode wyf dam alis
We loue no man þᵗat taketh kepe or charge
Where þᵗat we go. we wyl ben at oure large
Of alle men blessed mot he be
The wyse Astrologian daune Ptholome
That seyth þis ꝓprouerb in his almages

Þᵗat rekketh not who so hath þᵉ world in hand
By þis ꝓprouerb þᵘ shalt vndurstand

How merely þᵗat oþʳ folk fare
For certes olde dotard by ȝoure leue
Ȝe shal haue queynte ryth ynowh at eue
He is to gret a nygard þᵗat wyl wern
A man to lyhte a candel at his lantern
He shal haue neuʳ þeles lyht ꝑpardee
Haue þᵘ ynowh þe thar not pleyne þe
Þᵘ sayst also þat we make vs gay

In habetee made wᵗith chastitee ⁊and shame
Ȝe wymmen shulde apparel ȝow qd he
Not in tressed here ⁊and gay perre
As ꝑperles ne wᵗith golden clothes riche
Aftʳ þᵉ tyxt ne aftʳ þᵉ rubriche
I wyl not wyrche as muchel as a gnatte
þᵘ seydest als þᵗat I was lyke a catte
But who so wolde synge a catte skynne
Þenne wolde þᵉ catte wel dwelle in his Inne
And ȝif þᵉ catte skynne be slyke ⁊and gay
She wil not dwelle in house al day
But forth she wyl or any day be dawed
To shewe here skyn ⁊and gon a caterwawed

In feyth he shal not kepe me but ȝif me lust
Ȝet couth y make his berd so mot I þee
Þᵘ seydest eke þat þ̉er beth þinges þre
Þᵉ whiche troblen al þis erthe
And þᵗat no whyt may endure þᵉ ferþe
O leue ʆsir shrewe ihc shorte þi lyff
Ȝut pchest þᵘ ⁊and seyst an hateful wyf
Yrekened is for on of þis meschaunces
Beth þ̉er non oþʳ mane of resemblaunces
Þat ȝe may riken ȝoure ꝑparables to
But ȝif a sely wyf be oon of þo
Þᵘ likkenest wommans loue to helle
To bareyn lond þ̉ere watʳ may not dwelle
Þᵘ lykkenest hit also to wylde fyre
Þᵉ more hit brenneth þᵉ more hit hath desyre
To consume any þing þat brenned wolde be
Þᵘ sayst ryht as wormes eten a tree
Ryht so a wyf destrueth her housebande
Þis knowe þei þᵗat ben to wyfes bounde
Lordinges ryht þus as ȝe haue vndurstonde
Bare y styfly myn olde housband an honde
Þᵗat þus þei seyden in hure dronkenes
Berynge me an hond þinges of sklaundres
On Iankyn ⁊and on my nece also
O lord þᵉ peyne I dud hem ⁊and þᵉ wo
Ful gulteles by godes swete pyn
For as an hors I couth byte ⁊and whyne
I couth pleyne ⁊and ȝut was I in þᵉ gylt
Or elles ofte tymes I had be spylt
Who so fyrst cometh to Mille fyrst grynd
I playned fyrst ⁊and so was oure werre stynt
Þei were ful glad to excusen hem blyue
Of þing þᵗat þei agylt neuʳ in here lyue
Of wenches wolde y bere hem an hand
Whenne þᵗat for seke vn nethes þei myhte stand
Ȝyt tykeld I his hert for þat he
Wende I had of hym so gret chierte
I swore þat al my walkynge by nyht
Was for to aspie wenches / þat he dyht
Vndʳ þat coloᵘur had y many a myrth
For al such þing is gyuen vs in oure byrth
Desceyt wepynge ⁊and spynnynge god hath gyf
To womman kyndely whyles þei may lyue
And þus of oo þing I auaunt me
At þᵉ ende I had þᵉ best in Iche degree
By sleythe or force or some man̉er þing
As by continuel murmʳ and grucching
Namely abedde had þei meschaunce
Þ̉ere wolde y chyde ⁊and do hem no plesaunce
I wolde no lengʳ in þᵉ bed abide
Ȝif þᵗat I felde his arme ouʳ my syde
Tyl he had mad his raunsoum vn to me
Þenne wolde suffre hym to don his nycete
And þ̉erfore to euʳy man þis tale I telle
Wynne who so may al is for to selle
Wᵗith empty hand men may no haukes leur
For wynnynge wolde I al his lust endure
And maken a feyned appetite
And ȝut in bacoun had I neuʳ delyt
Þᵗat made me þᵗat I wolde eủere hym chyde
For þeyh þᵉ pope had sete hym beside
I wolde not spare hym at his owne bord
For by my trewthe I quytte hym word for word
As helpe me verrey god omipotent
Theyh ryth now I sholde make my testament
I owe hym no word þᵗat hit is quyt
I brouht hit aboute by my wyt
Þat he most gyf hit vp as for þᵉ best
Or elles had we neuʳ had rest
For þauh he loked as a wod lyoun
Ȝut sholde he fayle of his conclusioun
Then wolde I sey gode leef take kepe
How mekely loketh wylkyn oure sheepe
Come nere my spouse let me ba ȝoure cheke
Ȝe shuld be al pacient and meke
And haue a swete spyced conscience
Sythus ȝe pche so of Iopes pacience
Suffreth alwey sen ȝe can not pche
And but ȝe don c̉ertein we shal ȝow teche
Þat hit is feyre to haue a wyf in pes
Oon of vs moste bowen douteles
And sithus a man is more resonable
Þan womman is ȝe moste be sufferable
What eyleth ȝow to gruche þus ⁊and grone
Is hit for ȝe wolde haue my queynt al one
Why take ȝe hit loo haue hit euʳy del
Petre I shrewe ȝow but ȝe loue hit wel
For ȝif y wolde sulle my beal chose
I couthe walke as fresh as arose
But I wyl kepe hit for ȝoure owne toth
Ȝe ben to blame by god I sey ȝow soth
Such man̉er wordes had we an hand
Now wyl I speke of my fourthe houseband
My ferthe houseband was a reueloᵘur
This is to sey he had a ꝑparamoᵘur
And y was ȝong ⁊and ful of ragerie
Styborn and strong ⁊and Ioly as a pye
Bothe couth y daunce to harpes smale
And synge ywys as any Nyhtyngale
When y had dronken a drauht of swete wyn
Metullius þᵉ foule chyrle þᵉ swyn
Þat wᵗith a staf beraft his wyf her lyf
For she drank wyn þeyh y had ben his wyf
He sholde not haue daunted me fro drink
And aftʳ wyne on venus most y þenk
For als syker as colde engendreth hayle
A lykerous mouth most haue a lykerous teyle
In wymmen vinolent is non offence
Þis knowen lechours by exꝑperience
But lord cⁱst whenne y remembre me
Vpon my ȝouth ⁊and vpon my Iolytee
Hit tykeleth me aboute myn herte rote
Vn to þis day hit doth myn herte bote
That y had my world as my tyme
But age allas þᵗat wyl envenyme
Hath me beraft my beaute ⁊and my pyt
Let go fare wel þᵉ deuel go þ̉er wᵗith
Þᵉ floure is gon þ̉er is no more to telle
Þᵉ bran as y best can mote y selle
But ȝit to be ryht mery wyl y fonde
Now forth to telle of my fourthe housebande
I sey in herte I had gret despyte
Þat he of any oþʳ had delite
But he was quoyttby god ⁊and by þᵉ rode
I made hym of þᵉ same cloth an hood
Nouht of my body in no foule man̉ere
But certeynly y made folk such chier
Þat in his owne grees y made hym frye
For angʳ and for verrey Ielousie
By god in erthe I was his pʳgatorye
For wyche I hope his soule be in glorie
For god hit wot y sat ful ofte and song
When þᵗat his shoo ful bytterly hit wrong
For þ̉er was non saue god ⁊and he þᵗat wyst
In many wyse how sore þᵗat I hym twyst
He deyed whenne I cam from Ierlm
And lyth ygᵃue vndʳ þᵉ Rode beem
Al is his toumbe not so curious
As is þᵉ sepulchre of hym darius
Whiche þᵗat appelles wrouhte subtelly
Hit nys but wast to bury hym fresshely
Let hym fare wel god gyf his soule good rest
He is now in his gᵃue and in his chest
Now of my fythe housband wyl I telle
God lete his soule neuʳ come in helle
And ȝut was he to me þᵉ grettest shrew
That fele y nowe on my rybbes al by rewe
And euʳ shal vn to myn endyng day
But in oure bed he was fressh and gay
When þᵗat he wolde haue my beal chose
Lord so fayre þenne he wolde me glose
That þauh he had me beten on euʳy bon
He couth wynne my loue agayn anon
I trowe I loued hym þᵉ bettʳ for he
Was of his loue dangerous to me
We wymmen haue ȝif þᵗat y shal not lye
In this matere a queynte fantasie
Wayte what þing we may not lyhtly haue
Þ̉er aftʳ wyl we crie and craue
Forbede vs þing þat desyren we
Prees on vs faste ⁊and þen woln we flee
Wᵗith daunger oute we al oure chaffare
Grete prees at þᵉ market maketh dere ware
And to gret chep is halden at lyttel prys
This knoweth euʳy womman þat is wys
My fyfthe housband god his soule blesse
Wyche þᵗat y toke for loue ⁊and for no richesse
He some tyme was a clerk of Oxenford
And had laft scole ⁊and went at home to borde
Wᵗith my gossyp dwellynge in þᵉ toune
God haue her saule her name was Alisoun
She knewe myn hert and al my pⁱriuetee
Bet þan oure paryssh pst so mote y þee
To her bewryed y my counsel al
For had my housband pissed on a wal
Or don a þing þᵗat sholde haue cost his ly
To her and to an oþʳ worthy wyf
And to my nece wych þᵗat I loued wel
He wolde haue told his counsel euʳy dele
And so y dyd ful often god hit wot
Þᵗat made his face ofte rede and hot
For verrey shame ⁊and blamed hym self for he
Had told to me so grete a pⁱriuete
And so befel þᵗat ones in a lent
So ofte tymes I to my gossyp went
For euʳ ȝit I loued to be gay
And for to wowe in marche auerel ⁊and May
Fro hous to hous to herken sondry tales
That Iankyn clerk ⁊and my gossip dame Alys
And y my self in to feldes went
Myn housbond was at london al þat lent
I had þᵉ bettʳ leyser for to play
And for to see ⁊and eke for to be sey
Of lusty folk what wyste I where my gᵃce
Was shapen for to be or in what place
Þ̉erfore made y my visitaciouns
To vigles and to ꝓprocessiouns
To pchynges eke ⁊and to pylgⁱmages
To pleyes of miracles ⁊and of mariages
And wered vpon my gay skarlet gytes
Þese wormes ne þese moghtes ne þese mites
Vp on my ꝑperel freted hem neuʳ adele
And wost þᵘ why for þei were vsed so wel
Now wyl y telle forth what happed me
I sey þat in þᵉ feldes walked we
Tyl trewely we had such daliaunc
Tyl þᵉ clerk and I of my pʳueaunce
I spak to hym ⁊and seyde how þᵗat he
Ȝif y were a wydewe sholde wedde me
For certeynly y say for no bobaunce
Ȝut was y neuʳ wᵗith oute pʳueaunce
Of mariage ne of oþʳ þinges eke
I holde a mouse hert not worth a leek
That hath but oon hole to sterte to
And ȝif þat fayle þan is hit al ydo
But nowe ʆsir let me see what y shal sayne
A ha by god . I am in my tale agayne
Whenne þᵗat my fourthe houseband was on bere
I wepte algate ⁊and made sory chiere
As wyfes moten for hit is here vsage
And wᵗith my kercheff couerd my visage
But for þᵗat I was pʳueyed of a make
I wept but smal y vndurtake
To chyrche was my housband bore a morewe
Wᵗith neyhbores wyche for hym made sorewe
And Iankyn oure clerk was oon of þo
As helpe me god when y say hym go
Aftʳ þᵉ beer me þouht he had a payre
Of legges and of feet so clene and fayre
Al myn herte y ȝaf vn to his hold
He was y trowe a twenty wyntʳ old
And y was xlᵗⁱ ȝif y shal say þᵉ soth
And ȝut I had alwey a coltes toth
Gayte tothed I was ⁊and þᵗat becom me wel
I had þᵉ prent of seint venus seel
As helpe me god I was a lusty oo
Fayre ⁊and riche ȝong and wel begon
And trewely as myn housband tolde me
I had þᵉ best Quoniam þᵗat myhte be
Myn ascendaunt was Thaure ⁊and Mars þ̉erin
Allas þᵗat euer loue was synne
I folowed ay myn inclinacioun
By v̉ertue of my constellacioun
That made me I couth not wᵗith drawe
My chambre of venus from a good felawe
What shuld y say but at þᵉ moneths ende
Þis Ioly clerk Iankyn þᵗat was so hende
Hath wedded me wᵗith gret solempnete
And to hym gaf I al þᵉ lond and fee
Þat euʳ was me gyuen þ̉er before
But aftʳward repented me ful sore
He nolde suffre no þing of my lust
By god he smot me ones wᵗith his fust
For þᵗat y rent out of his book a leef
Þat of þᵗat strookꝭes my Ere wex al deef
Styborn I was as is a leones
And of my tonge a verrey Iangelares
And walke y wolde as y had don byfore
Fro hous to hous al þeyh he had hit swore
For whiche ful often tyme he wolde pche
And me olde Romayn gestes teche
How she symplicius gallus lost her lyf
And her forsook for terme of al her lyf
Not but for openhed he her say
Lokynge out of his dore vpon a day

Þᵉ rihtfuƚƚ Iuge whiche þᵗat ȝe haue serued
Shaƚƚ gyf hit ȝow as ȝe haue hit deserued
And whenne þis þing was seyd as y deuise
Men lad hem forth to doon þᵉ sacrifice
But when þei were vn to þᵉ p̉lace ybrouht
To telle shortly þᵉ conclusioun̄
Þei nolde encense ne sacrifice ryht nouht
But on here knees þei setten hem adoun̄
Wᵗith humble hert ⁊and seyde deuocioun̄
And losten here hedes boþe in þᵉ place
Here saules wente to þᵉ king of gᵃrace
Þis maximus þᵗat saw þis þing betyde
Wᵗith pytous teres told hit anon riht
Þᵗat he here saules sauh to heuene glyde
Wᵗith ang̉elus fuƚƚ of clerenesse ⁊and of lyht
And wᵗith his word conủerted many a wyht
For whiche Almachus dud hym so to bete
Wᵗith whyppes of lede til he his lif can lete
Cecely hym toke ⁊and buryed hym anon̄
By tyburce ⁊and valerian softely
Wᵗith Inne hure buriynge place vndre aston̄
And aftᵘur þis Almachius hastely
Bad his ministres fechen openly
Cecely so she myhte in p̉resence
Do sacrifice ⁊and Iubit̉er encense
But þo þat were conủerted þourh here wyse lore
Wepten fuƚƚ sore ⁊and gaf credence
Vn to here word ⁊and crieden more ⁊and more
Cⁱristes godes sone wᵗithoute difference
Is verrey god þis is aƚƚ oure sentence
Þᵗat hath so good a s̉eruant hym to s̉erue
Þus wᵗith a voyce we trowe þauh we sterue
Almachius þat herd of þis þing
Bad fecche Cecely þat he myht see
And allerfyrst þis was his askyng
What maner of womman art þᵘou qduod he
I am a genteƚƚ wōmman boren qduod she
I aske þe þauh y þᵉ greue
Of þi religioun̄ ⁊and of þi beleeue

Qduod she þᵗat woldest two answeres conclude

div.l: In oon demande ȝe asketh lewdely
Almache answered to þᵗat similitude
Of my power ⁊and she answered hym þis
Ȝoure myht qduod she fuƚƚ lytteƚƚ is to drede
For euᵘury mortales mannes power nys
But ylyke a bleddre ful of wynd ywys
For wᵗith a neeldes poynt when hit is blowe
May al þᵉ bost of hit be leyd fuƚƚ lowe
Fuƚƚ wrongfully begynnen ȝe qduod she
And ȝut in wrong is þi ꝑperseuerance
Wost þᵘou not how oure myhty pⁱrinces free
Ben thus cōmmanded ⁊and made ordinance
Þᵗat euᵘury wyght cⁱristene shaƚƚ haue penaunce
But he his cⁱristendome wᵗith seye
And goon aƚƚ quyte ȝif he hit wyl reneye
Ȝoure pⁱrinces erren as ȝoure nobley doth
Qduod þo Cecely ⁊and wᵗith a wood sentence
Ȝe make vs gulty ⁊and hit is not sooth
For he þᵗat knewe wel ȝoure Innocence
To cⁱrist ⁊and for we bere a cⁱristen name
Ȝe putten on vs a cⁱrime ⁊and blame
But we þat knowen þilke name so
For v̉ertuose we may not hit sey
Almacheus answered chese oon of þᵉ two
Do sacrifice or cⁱristendome reneye
Þᵗat þᵘou mayst nowe scapen by þat wey
At whiche þis holy ⁊and blesfuƚƚ mayde
Began for to lawhe ⁊and to þᵉ Iugge sche seyde
O Iuge confused in þi nycete
Wilt þᵘou þat I reneye Innocence
To make me a wycked wyght qduod she
Lo he dissimyleth here in audience
He stareth ⁊and wodeth in his adủertence
To whome Almachus O vnsely wrecche
Ne wost þᵘou not howe my myth may streche
Hath not oure myhty pⁱrince to me ygyuen
Ȝe bothe power and auctorite
To make folk to dyen or to lyuen
Why spekest þᵘou so proudely þen to me
I speke hit not but studefastly qduod she
Nouht proudely for I sey as for my syde
I hate dedly þilke vice of pⁱride
And ȝif þᵘou drede nouht a sooth to here
Þenne wyƚƚ y shewe aƚƚ openly by ryht
Þᵗat þᵘou hast made a fuƚƚ grete lesyng here
Þᵘou sayst þi pⁱrinces haue þe gyuen myht
Bothe to sleen ⁊and for to quyken a wyght
Þᵘou þᵗat ne mayst but oonly my lyf to reue
Þᵘou ne hast noon̄ other power ne leue
But þᵘou mayst see þin pⁱrinces haue þe maked
Ministre of deth for ȝif þᵘou speke of mo
Þᵘou lyest for þi power is fuƚƚ naked
Do wey þi boldenesse seyde Almachius þoo
And to oure goddes sacrifice þᵘou do
I ne recche what wrong þᵘou me ꝓprofre
For y can suffre hit as a philosofre
But þilke wrong may y not endure
Þᵗat þᵘou spekest of oure goddes qduod he
Cecely answered o nyce creature
Þᵘou saydest no word sithns þᵘou spake to me
Þᵗat y ne knewe þ̉er wᵗith þi nicetee
And þᵗat þᵘou were in euᵘury maner wyse
Alewed officer ⁊and a veyne Iustice
Þ̉ere lakketh no þing to þin vttre eyen
Þᵗat þᵘou nart blynd for þing þᵗat we seen aƚƚlle
What is a stoon þat we may weƚƚ aspien
Þᵗat ilke ston a god þᵘou woldest calle
I rede þe lat þin hand vpon hit falle
And taste hit wel ⁊and a ston þᵘou shalt hit fynde
Sithns þᵗat þᵘou seest not wᵗith þin eyen blynde
Hit is a shame þᵗat þᵉ peple shaƚƚ
So skorn þe ⁊and lawhe at þi folie
For cōmmenly wymmen wote hit wel ouᵘuraƚƚ
Þᵗat myhty god is in his heuenes hye
And þese ymages wel þᵘou mayst aspie
To þe ne to hem self may not ꝓprofyte
For in her effecte þei beth not worth a myte
Þis ⁊and such oþᵘur wordes hath sche
And he wex wroth ⁊and bad men shulde here lede
Home to here hous ⁊and in her hous qduod he
Brenne her right in a bath of flammes rede
And as he bad right so was doon þᵉ dede
For in a bath þei can her faste setten
And nyht ⁊and day þ̉er vndᵘur feyr feyr þei beten
Þᵉ long nyht ⁊and eke þᵉ day also
For aƚƚ þᵉ fyre ⁊and eke þᵉ bathes hete
She satte aƚƚ cold ⁊and felt of hit no wo
Hit made here no drope for to swete
Ryht in þᵗat bath here lyf she moste lete
For he Almache wᵗith fuƚƚ wycked entent
To sleen her in þᵉ bath his sonde he he sent
Þre strokes in þᵉ necke he smote her þo
Þᵉ tormentoᵘurs for no man̉er chaunce
He myhte not smyte al her necke a two
And for þ̉er was þat tyme an ordinaunce
Þᵗat no man sholde do suche penaunce
Þᵉ fourthe strok to smyten softe or sore
Þis turmentoᵘurs durste smyte no more
But half ded wᵗith here necke corue þ̉ere
He lete here lie ⁊and on his wey he went
Þᵉ cⁱristene folk whiche aboute here were
Wᵗith schetes haue þᵉ blod fuƚƚ fayre hent
Þre dayes lyued she in þis torment
And neuᵘur cesed hem þᵉ feyth to teche
Þᵗat she had fostred hem she gan to p̉reche
And hem she gaf here mebles ⁊and here þing
And to þᵉ pope vrban betok here þo
And seide I aske þis of heuene kyng
To haue respit þre dayes ⁊and no mo
To recōmmaunde to ȝow or þᵗat y go
Þese saules ⁊and þᵗat y myhte do wyrche
Here of myn hous ꝑperpetuelly a chyrche
Seynt vrban wᵗith his dekenes pⁱriuely
Þᵉ body fette ⁊and buried here be nyht
Among his oþᵘure seyntꝰus honestely
Here hous þᵉ chyrche of seint Cecely hiht
Seint vrban halewed hit as he wel myht
In whiche vn to þis day in noble wyse
Men don to cⁱrist ⁊and to his seyntꝰus seruice
When þᵗat told was þᵉ lyf of seynt Cecely
Er we fully had riden fyue myle
At boghton̄ vndᵘur blee vs can atake
A man þᵗat cloþed was in clothes blake
And vnder þᵗat cloth was a white surplys
His hakeney þᵗat was a pomel grys
So swette þᵗat hit wondᵘur was to see
Hit semed he had pⁱriked myles þre
Þᵉ hors eke þᵗat þᵉ ȝōman rode vpon̄
So swatte þᵗat vn nethus myhte he goon̄
Abouten þᵉ peytreƚƚ stood þᵉ foom fuƚƚ heyh
He was of fome flekked as a peygh
A male tweyfold on his cropere lay
Hit semed þat he caried lyte array
Al lyhte for somer rood þis worthi man
And in myn hert wondren I began
What þᵗat he was tyl þᵗat y vndurstod
Howe þat his cloke was sowed to his hod
For whiche whenne y longe had avised me /
I demed hym some Chanon for to be
His hatte hang at his bak doun by a lace
For he had riden more þan trot or pase
He had ay pⁱriked lyke as he were wood
A clote leef he had vndᵘur his hood
For swete ⁊and for to kepe his hed fro hete
But hit was Ioy for to seen hym swete
His forhed drepped as a styllatorie
Were fuƚƚ of plantayne ⁊and ꝑperatorie
And whenne þat he cam he gan to crie
God saue qduod he þis Ioly company
Faste haue I pⁱriked qduod he for ȝoure sake
By cause þat y wolde ȝow a take
To ryden in þis mery company
His ȝōman eke was fuƚƚ of curtesye
And seide syres nowe in þᵉ morowe tyde
Oute of ȝoure Ostelrie I sawe ȝowe ride
And warned here my lord ⁊and my souereygne
Whiche þᵗat to ride wᵗith ȝow is fuƚƚ fayne
For his disport he loueth daliaunce
Frend for þi warnyng god gyf þᵉ good chaunce
Þenne seyde oure ost c̉erteyne hit wolde seme
Þi lord were wyse ⁊and so y may wel deme
He is fuƚƚ iocunde as dar y ley
Can he ouht telle a mery tale or twey
Wᵗith þᵉ whiche he glade may þis companye
Who ʆsir my lord ȝe wᵗith oute lie
He can of myrthe ⁊and eke of Iolyte
Nouħt but ynouħ also ʆsir tresteth me
And ȝe hym knewe as weƚƚ as do y
Ȝe wolde wondren howe weƚƚ ⁊and craftely
He coutħ wyrk ⁊and þat in sondry wyse
He hath take on hym many a gret empⁱrise
Whiche were fuƚƚ hard for any þᵗat is here
To bringe aboute but þei of hym hit lere
As homely as he rydeth among ȝowe
Ȝif ȝe hym knewe hit wolde be for ȝoure prowe
Ȝe wolde not forgon his acqueyntance

And for aƚƚ þᵗat we faylen of oure desire
For euᵘur we lakken of oure conclusioun̄
To muche folk we don illusioun̄
And borowe gold be hit a pound or two
Or ten or twelf or many sūmmes mo
And maken hem wene at þᵉ leste wey
Þᵗat of a pounde he couth make twey
Ȝut is hit fals ⁊and ay we haue good hope
Hit for to don ⁊and aftᵘur hit we grope
But þᵗat science is so ferre vs beforn̄
We mowe not aƚƚ þeyh we had sworn̄
hit ouᵘurtake hit slydeth awey so fast
Hit wyl vs make beggares at þᵉ last
Whiles þis ȝōman was þus in his talkyng
This Chanoun̄ drowe hym nere ⁊and herd aƚƚ þing
What þis ȝōman spake for suspecioun̄
Of mennes speche euᵘur had þis Chanoun̄
For Caton seyth he þat gulty is
Demeth aƚƚ þing men speke of hym ywys
Þᵗat causeth hym he can so neyh drawe
To his ȝōman to herken of his sawe
And þus he seyde vn to his ȝōman þo
Hald þᵘou þi pes ⁊and speke no word mo
For ȝif þᵘou do þᵘou shalt hit dere abye
Þᵘou sklaunderest me here in þis companye
And diskeuerest þat þᵘou sholdest hyde
Ȝe qduod oure ost telle on what so wyl betyde
Of aƚƚ þis thretyng rek þe not a myte
In feyth qduod he no more y do but lyte
And whenne þᵉ chanoun̄ sawe hit wolde not be
But his ȝōman wolde telle his pⁱriuete
He fled awey for verrey sorowe ⁊and shame
A qduod þᵉ ȝōman here shaƚƚ rise a game
Aƚƚ þat y can anon nowe wyl y telle
Sen he is gon þᵉ foule fend hym quelle
For neuᵘur here aftᵘur wyl y wᵗith hym mete
For peny ne for pound y ȝow behete
He þᵗat me brouht fyrst to þat game
Or þᵗat he dye sorowe haue he ⁊and shame
For hit is ernest to me by my feyth
Þᵗat fele y wel what so any man seyth
And ȝut for al my smert ⁊and al my gref
For al my sorowe labour ⁊and mys chief
I couth neuᵘur leue hit in no wyse
Now wolde god my witte myhte suffice
To telle aƚƚ þᵗat longeth to þat art
And neuᵘurþeles ȝut wyl y telle ȝowe part
Sen þᵗat my lord is goon y wiƚƚ not spare
Such þing as y knowe y wyƚƚ declare
The canons omane
Wyth þis chanon I dwelled haue vij ȝere
And of þis science am I neuᵘur þᵉ nere
And aƚƚ þat I had y haue lost þ̉erby
And god wot so haue many mo þan I
Þ̉ere I was wont to be rith fressh ⁊and gay
Of clothinge ⁊and oþᵘur good array
Nowe may y were an hose vpon myn hede
And where my coloᵘur was fresh ⁊and rede
Nowe is it wanne ⁊and a leden hewe
Who so hit vseth sore wyl he rewe
And of my swynk blered is my eye
Lo such auantage is to multiplie
Þᵗat slydynge science hath mad me so bare
Þᵗat y haue no good where þᵗat euᵘur y fare
And ȝut I am endited so þ̉erby
Of gold þᵗat I haue borowed trewely
Þᵗat whiles I lyue I shaƚƚ hit quyte neuᵘur
Lat euᵘury man be ware by me for euᵘur
What man̉er man þᵗat casteth hym þ̉erto
Ȝif he cōntinue I holde his thryft doo
For so helpe me god þ̉erby shaƚƚ he not wynne
But empte his purs ⁊and make his wit thinne
And whenne he þourh his madnesse ⁊and folye
Hath lost his owne good þourh Iupardie
Þenne he exciteth oþ̉ere folk þ̉erto
To lose here good as he hym self hath do
For vn to shrewes ioy hit is ⁊and ese
To haue her felawes in peyne ⁊and in disese
Thus was y ones lerned of a clerk
Of þᵗat no charge y wyl speke of oure werk
Whenne we be þ̉ere as we shaƚƚ exercice
Oure eluish craft we semeth wondᵘur wyse
Oure termes ben so clergeal ⁊and queynte
I blowe þᵉ fyre til þᵗat myn herte feynte
What shulde I telle eke of ꝓproporcioun̄
Of þinges whiche þᵗat we wyrche vp ⁊and doıı̄un
As on v or vj vnces may wel be
Of syluer or some oþᵘur quantite
And bysy me to telle ȝowe þᵉ names
Of orpiment brent bones yren squames
Þᵗat in to poudᵘur grounden beth fuƚƚ smale
And in an erthen pot how put is ale
And salt yputte in ⁊and also pauꝑper
Byforn þis pauper þᵗat I spak of here
And wel ykouered wᵗith alaumpe of glas
And of muche oþᵘur þing what þᵗat þ̉er was
And of þᵉ potte ⁊and glasses enbityng
Þᵗat of þᵉ Eyre myhte passe oute no þing
And of þᵉ esy fyre ⁊and smert also alsoo alsoo
Whiche þat made ⁊and of þᵉ care ⁊and wo
Þᵗat we hadden in oure matiers sublymyng
And almagamyng ⁊and calcenyng
Of quyk siluer ycleped mercurie crudde
For aƚƚ oþᵘur sleigthes we can not conclude
Oure orpiment ⁊and sublymed m̉ercurie
Oure grounde lytarge eke on þᵉ Porferie
Of yche of þese of vnces a certeyne
Nouht helpeth vs oure laboᵘur is in veyne
Ne eke oure spiritus ascensioun̄
Ne oure matiers þᵗat lyn aƚƚ fix adoun̄
Mowe in oure wyrkyng noþing avayle
For lost is oure laboᵘur ⁊and oure trauayle
And aƚƚ þᵉ cost a twenty deueƚƚ wey
Is lost also whiche we vpon hit ley
Þ̉er is also fuƚƚ many an oþᵘur þing
Þat is to oure craft apꝑperteynyng
Þeyh I by ordre hem not reherce here can
By cause þᵗat y am a lewde man
Ȝut wyl y telle hem as þei come in mynde
Þeigh I can not sette hem in her kynde
As bole armonyak verdegres boras
And sondry vesselles made of erthe ⁊and glas
Oure vrnalles ⁊and oure descensories
Violes crosseletes ⁊and sublimatories
Concurbites ⁊and Alambikes eke
And other such dere ynowe aleke
What nedeth hit for to reherce hem aƚƚ
Watres rubysshing ⁊and bolles gaƚƚ
Arsenek sal armoniak ⁊and brinston̄
And erbes couth y telle eke many oon̄
Egremoyne Valerian ⁊and lunarie
And oþᵘure such ȝif me lust for to tarie
Oure laumpes brenneth boþe nyht ⁊and day
To bringe aboute oure craft ȝif þᵗat we may
Oure furneys eke of calcinacioun̄
And of watres Allificacioun̄
Vn slekked lyme chalk ⁊and gleyre of an eye
Poudres diủerse asshes dong pysse ⁊and cleye
Sered poketꝰus salpetre vitriole
And diuerse fyres ymade of wode ⁊and cole
Salt tartre Alkaly ⁊and sal p̉reparate
And combust matiers ⁊and coagulate
Cley made wᵗith hors or mannes here ⁊and oyle
Of tartre Alum glas berm wort ⁊and argoyle
